race.name: Ouray Gravel Grinder
race.tagline: Where gravel meets the sky - high-altitude suffering in Colorado's Switzerland

distances.name: Alpine Loop
distances.description: High elevation loop topping 12,000+ ft via Engineer and Cinnamon Passes

distances.name: Black Bear Pass
distances.description: Classic San Juan jeep road - most dangerous 4x4 road in Colorado

terrain.description: Extreme high-altitude San Juan Mountain passes on jeep roads, topping above 12,000 ft

typical.conditions: High altitude mountain weather, 72-81 thunderstorm days/year, monsoon season July-August, hypothermia risk

uniqueCharacteristics: Alpine Loop and Black Bear Pass routes

logistics.explanation: Remote but accessible. Montrose airport is 35 miles, Durango 70 miles. Small-town services with limited hours. Requires 5+ days for altitude acclimation. Not extreme remoteness but significant planning required.

length.explanation: At 80 miles, this falls in the substantial distance category, though research indicates this may reference the longer Ouray 100 format. Jill Homer described "42,000 feet of ascent in just 100 miles" - a distance that becomes a full day of high-altitude suffering regardless of the exact mileage.

technicality.explanation: Jill Homer described climbs as "straight up a 45-percent grade" through the San Juan Mountains terrain. The Hayden Pass section she witnessed represents typical technical challenges with jeep roads, bare rock sections, and grades that often require significant hike-a-bike above 12,000 ft.

elevation.explanation: Homer's account of "42,000 feet of ascent in just 100 miles" confirms extreme climbing totals that exceed most gravel events. The San Juan Mountains setting means this elevation gain occurs at already-high altitude, compounding the physiological impact of each vertical foot.

climate.explanation: San Juan Range sees 72-81 thunderstorm days annually - Colorado's highest. Monsoon season brings afternoon storms that can shift from clear skies to hail within minutes. Lightning exposure above treeline creates severe risk, with the golden rule being below treeline by noon during storm season.

altitude.explanation: Starting at 7,792 ft and climbing through passes above 12,000 ft creates severe physiological impact. Even acclimatized riders experience 20-30% power loss at these elevations. The San Juan Mountains represent some of the highest sustained gravel riding in the Lower 48.

adventure.explanation: Homer noted that despite the suffering on Hayden Pass, "it was an incredible place." The San Juan Mountains' combination of 13,000+ ft peaks, historic mining routes, and technical challenges creates bucket-list territory that pushes riders to absolute limits while delivering unforgettable scenery.

prestige.explanation: Research reveals no specific organized "Ouray Gravel Grinder" event exists. The area attracts dedicated bikepacking communities through events like the Silverton Project, but lacks standalone race prestige. Nearby Telluride Gravel Race draws regional recognition, but not elite fields.

race_quality.explanation: As there is no organized 'Ouray Gravel Grinder' event, there's no race organization to evaluate. Self-supported riding means no aid stations, no course marking, no official support. Riders are on their own.

experience.explanation: Despite lack of organization, the experience itself is unforgettable - for better or worse. The scenery is 10/10, the challenge is severe, and completing routes like the Alpine Loop or Imogene Pass creates lasting memories. You'll remember this forever.

community.explanation: Homer's crew support role indicates some community involvement, with opportunities for non-racers to participate through course access and aid station support. However, the lack of an established standalone event limits the development of race-specific traditions and dedicated participant culture.

field_depth.explanation: No organized standalone competition means no competitive field depth. While individual riders like those in Homer's report tackle the terrain, this represents self-supported adventure riding rather than structured racing with elite or deep amateur fields to measure against.

value.explanation: Without entry fees (no organized event), the riding itself offers exceptional value. Outstanding terrain accessible to anyone who can get there and is prepared for the challenge. Hot springs recovery is a bonus.

expenses.explanation: Moderate costs with Montrose airport access and lodging at $200-300/night in Ouray. Hot springs recovery options add value to accommodation costs. The San Juan Mountains location requires significant time investment for proper altitude acclimation, extending trip duration and total expenses.

race.notes: No clearly documented recurring 'Ouray Gravel Grinder' event with fixed organization. Scoring reflects the self-supported gravel riding experience in the Ouray/San Juan region based on Alpine Loop, Black Bear Pass, and Imogene Pass routes. Course profile scores reflect the exceptional difficulty of the terrain; editorial scores reflect the lack of organized event infrastructure. For organized racing, consider nearby Telluride Gravel Race.

final_verdict.one_liner: The Ouray Gravel Grinder doesn't exist as an organized race, but the San Juan Mountains will humble your FTP and test your ability to push a bike up 13,000-foot passes.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You can't race what isn't there, but if you're drawn to self-supported suffering in Colorado's most brutal terrain, bring a mountain bike and your hiking legs. The Alpine Loop and Imogene Pass will have you walking more than riding above 12,000 feet, and afternoon thunderstorms don't negotiate with your Strava segment dreams. This is bikepacking country masquerading as a gravel destination.
final_verdict.alternatives: Hit the actual Telluride Gravel Race 25 miles away for organized pain with 10,000 feet of climbing, or SBT GRVL in Steamboat for high-altitude suffering with better logistics and real competition instead of just you versus gravity.

course_description.character: Ouray serves up 80 miles of high-altitude punishment across mining roads that were never meant for bicycles. You'll grind through San Juan valleys on County Road 23 before the real show beginsâ€”12,000-foot alpine passes where your 34x42 becomes a prayer. This isn't gravel racing, it's controlled mountaineering on two wheels.

suffering_zones.label: County Road Reality Check
suffering_zones.desc: Rolling ranch roads through Ridgway Valley give you false confidence before the climbing starts. Use this time to dial in nutrition because things get serious fast.

suffering_zones.label: Alpine Loop Entry
suffering_zones.desc: The road tilts skyward toward Engineer Pass and your easy spinning ends forever. Welcome to 4WD mining roads where 10% grades are considered gentle.

suffering_zones.label: Engineer Pass Summit
suffering_zones.desc: At 12,800 feet, your lungs find out what thin air actually means. The descent is loose rock and exposure that'll make you religious about tire pressure.

suffering_zones.label: Cinnamon Pass Finale
suffering_zones.desc: Just when your legs are cooked, another 12,600-foot pass appears. The babyhead rocks and moon dust surface will test whatever's left in your soul.

course_description.signature_challenge: Engineer and Cinnamon passes back-to-back above 12,000 feet, where even Tour de France climbers end up walking sections. The altitude turns your FTP into a cruel joke, and the loose rock surfaces make every pedal stroke a negotiation with gravity.
